section.name: s1
section.heading: Citation
section.content: These regulations may be cited as the Factories and Industrial Undertakings Regulations.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In these regulations, unless the context otherwise requires—
section.def: dangerous occurrence (危險事故) means any occurrence specified in the First Schedule; (L.N. 132 of 1969)

executive (幹事會), in relation to a trade union, means the body to which the management of the affairs of the trade union is entrusted by the members and also means any person for the time being carrying out the functions of a president, chairman, vice-chairman, secretary or treasurer of a trade union; (L.N. 132 of 1969)
fire-resisting material (耐火物料) means a building material certified by the building authority to be fire-resisting;
identity card (身分證) means an identity card issued under the Registration of Persons Ordinance (Cap. 177); (L.N. 132 of 1969)
material (物料) includes waste material and debris; (L.N. 157 of 1978)
mill-gearing (傳動裝置) includes every shaft, wheel, drum and pulley and every other appliance by which motion or power is communicated to any machine;
overburden (覆蓋層), in respect of a quarry, means any other substance which overlies the granite, porphyry or limestone which is extracted in the quarry; (L.N. 29 of 1969)
trade union (職工會) means a trade union which is registered under the Trade Unions Ordinance (Cap. 332). (L.N. 132 of 1969)

part.name: P2A
part.heading: Medical Examinations of Persons Employed to Work Underground

section.name: s16A
section.heading: Application of Part IIA
section.leadIn: This Part shall apply to the following industrial undertakings—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: mines;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: quarries; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: industrial undertakings involving tunnelling operations.

section.name: s16B
section.heading: Register of persons employed underground in industrial undertaking

subsection.content: The proprietor of every industrial undertaking to which this Part applies shall maintain or cause to be maintained therein a register in accordance with this regulation.

subsection.leadIn: The register shall be in the prescribed form and shall in respect of every person employed to work underground in the industrial undertaking— (See Second Schedule, Form 1)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: specify his name and residential address;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: specify the number of his identity card, if any;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: specify his date of birth;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: contain a full face photograph of the person;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: specify the date on which he first commenced to work underground in the industrial undertaking; and

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: specify the date of every medical examination undergone by him in accordance with regulation 16C(3).

section.name: s16C
section.heading: Employees not to work underground unless examined medically

subsection.leadIn: Subject to regulations 16D and 16E, no person shall be permitted to commence to work underground in an industrial undertaking to which this Part applies unless within the month preceding the date on which the person first commences so to work—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the proprietor has engaged a medical practitioner to examine the person medically in accordance with paragraph (3); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the senior occupational health officer has issued a certificate under paragraph (4) that the person is fit to work underground in such an industrial undertaking. (L.N. 248 of 1982)

subsection.leadIn: No person under the age of 21 years—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: who is employed to work underground in an industrial undertaking to which this Part applies; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: who has been so employed for more than 12 months,

subsection.continued: shall be permitted to continue in such employment at any time unless within the preceding period of 12 months—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: the proprietor has engaged a medical practitioner to examine the person medically in accordance with paragraph (3); and

content.leadIn: the senior occupational health officer has issued a certificate under paragraph (4) that the person is fit to work underground in such an industrial undertaking: (L.N. 248 of 1982)

subsection.proviso: Provided that a person under the age of 21 years who is employed at the date of commencement* of this regulation to work underground in an industrial undertaking to which this Part applies may continue to be so employed for a period not exceeding 3 months from such date, notwithstanding that he has not been examined medically as required under subparagraph (i) of this paragraph.

subsection.leadIn: Where any person is required to be examined medically for the purposes of this regulation—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the proprietor of the industrial undertaking in which the person is employed or is to be employed to work underground shall complete Part I of the prescribed medical examination report in duplicate; (See Second Schedule, Form 2)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person required to be examined shall complete Part II of the prescribed medical examination report in duplicate; and (See Second Schedule, Form 2)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: a medical practitioner shall carry out a medical examination of the person, and—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: complete Part III of the prescribed medical examination report in duplicate in respect of the person; (See Second Schedule, Form 2)

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: forward 1 copy of the completed report to the senior occupational health officer; and (L.N. 248 of 1982)

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: retain 1 copy of the completed report.

subsection.content: Where the senior occupational health officer receives a medical examination report under paragraph (3) in respect of any person, he shall forthwith forward a certificate in the prescribed form and in accordance with the report to the proprietor of the industrial undertaking by whom the medical practitioner has been engaged. (See Second Schedule, Form 3)
The expenses of the medical examination of any person for the purposes of this regulation shall in no case be payable by or recoverable from the person.

section.name: s16D
section.heading: Exemption from medical examination where employee examined within previous 12 months

subsection.leadIn: Any person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: who has attained the age of 21 years,

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: who is or has at any time been employed to work underground in an industrial undertaking to which this Part applies,

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: who has been examined medically in accordance with regulation 16C(3) for the purposes of such employment; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: in respect of whom the senior occupational health officer has, as a result of the medical examination, issued a certificate of fitness under regulation 16C(4), (L.N. 248 of 1982)

subsection.continued: may, at any time within 12 months after the date of the medical examination—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: be re-employed to work underground in the industrial undertaking; or

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: be employed, subject to paragraph (2), to work underground in any other industrial undertaking to which this Part applies,

subsection.continued: notwithstanding that in respect of his re-employment in such industrial undertaking, or his employment in such other industrial undertaking, the person has not been examined medically as required under regulation 16C(1)(a).

subsection.content: Before employing any person under paragraph (1)(ii), the proprietor of the industrial undertaking shall obtain from the senior occupational health officer a copy of the certificate issued under regulation 16C(4) in respect of the medical examination. (L.N. 248 of 1982)

section.name: s16E
section.heading: Exemption from medical examination where work unlikely to take more than 6 months to complete
section.content: Where any person who has attained the age of 21 years is to be employed to work underground in any industrial undertaking to which this Part applies, and the Commissioner for Labour or any officer authorized in writing by him is satisfied that the underground work on which the person is to be employed is unlikely to take more than 6 months to complete, the Commissioner for Labour or the authorized officer may give written permission for the employment of the person on such work for such period, not exceeding 6 months, as the Commissioner for Labour or the authorized officer shall specify, notwithstanding that in respect of such employment, the person has not been examined medically as required under regulation 16C(1)(a).

subsection.leadIn: At the request of an authorized member of the executive of any trade union which in the opinion of the Commissioner for Labour, or any officer authorized in writing by him, represents any person under the age of 21 years who is employed to work underground in any industrial undertaking to which this Part applies, the Commissioner for Labour or the authorized officer shall supply to such member the following information in respect of the person so employed—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: his name;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: his identity card number, if any;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: his date of birth;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the date which, in the latest medical examination report received by the senior occupational health officer under regulation 16C(4) in respect of the person, is specified as the date on which he first commenced to work underground in the industrial undertaking or as the proposed date on which he was to first commence so to work; and (L.N. 248 of 1982)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the nature of his occupation,

subsection.continued: and shall produce for inspection to such member the latest certificate issued under regulation 16C(4) in respect of the person so employed.

subsection.leadIn: No—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: proprietor of an industrial undertaking to which this Part applies; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: public officer,

subsection.continued: shall disclose to any person any medical information which is obtained on the examination of a person in accordance with regulation 16C(3), unless—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: the person to whom the information relates consents to the disclosure;

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: the information is disclosed to a public officer acting in the course of his duty; or

paragraph.name: iii
paragraph.content: the disclosure of the information is permitted or required under any enactment.

section.name: s17
section.heading: Report of accidents resulting in death or incapacity

subsection.leadIn: Where an accident in an industrial undertaking results in—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the death of a person at the time of the accident or immediately thereafter; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: serious bodily injury to a person,

subsection.continued: a report of the accident stating the name of the person, the nature of the injury and the time, place and circumstances of the accident shall be made orally or in writing by the proprietor of the industrial undertaking within 24 hours after the accident—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: to an occupational safety officer, where the accident occurs in an industrial undertaking other than a quarry; or (32 of 2000 s. 48)

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: to the Superintendent of Mines, where the accident occurs in a quarry,

subsection.continued: and to the police station nearest to the place of accident, where the accident results in death.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to paragraph (4), where an accident in an industrial undertaking results in—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the death of a person at the time of the accident or immediately thereafter;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: serious bodily injury to a person; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the incapacity, for a period exceeding 3 days immediately following the accident, of a person for any employment which he was capable of undertaking at the time of the accident,

subsection.continued: a report of the accident (containing the particulars specified in paragraph (5)) shall, in addition to any report required to be made under paragraph (1), be made in writing by the proprietor of the industrial undertaking within 7 days after the accident—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: to an occupational safety officer, where the accident occurs in an industrial undertaking other than a quarry; or (32 of 2000 s. 48)

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: to the Superintendent of Mines, where the accident occurs in a quarry.

subsection.leadIn: Where a person who is injured in an accident dies subsequently as a result of the injury and the death comes to the notice of the proprietor of the industrial undertaking, the proprietor shall, in addition to any report which he may have made or is required to make under paragraphs (1)(b) and (2)(b) or (c), report the death orally or in writing within 24 hours after it comes to his notice—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to an occupational safety officer, where the accident has occurred in an industrial undertaking other than a quarry; or (32 of 2000 s. 48)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to the Superintendent of Mines, where the accident has occurred in a quarry,

subsection.continued: and to the police station nearest to the place of the accident.

subsection.content: No report is required under paragraph (2) if notice of the accident has been given under section 15 of the Employees’ Compensation Ordinance (Cap. 282).

subsection.leadIn: A report under paragraph (2) shall contain—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the name and address of the proprietor of the industrial undertaking;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the name, occupation and address of the deceased or injured person and his sex, age and identity card number;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the date and particulars of the accident; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the nature of the injury, stating whether death or incapacity was caused by the injury.

subsection.content: For the purposes of paragraphs (1) and (2) a person shall be deemed to have suffered serious bodily injury in an accident if he is admitted to a hospital immediately following the accident for observation or treatment.

subsection.leadIn: Every dangerous occurrence which occurs in an industrial undertaking, whether any personal injury has been caused or not, shall be reported by the proprietor of the industrial undertaking within 24 hours of its occurrence— (L.N. 7 of 1975)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of an industrial undertaking other than a quarry, to an occupational safety officer; and (32 of 2000 s. 48)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a quarry, to the Superintendent of Mines. (L.N. 29 of 1969)

subsection.content: Every report made under this regulation shall be in writing, and in addition to any report required under regulation 17, and shall include particulars of the time of the occurrence of the accident, any damage to any building, machinery or plant in the industrial undertaking in which the accident occurred, and the circumstances in which the accident occurred. (L.N. 29 of 1969)

section.name: s19
section.heading: Application of regulations 17 and 18
section.content: The provisions of regulations 17 and 18 shall not be applicable in the case of any accident which is required to be reported under the provisions of section 47 of the Mining Ordinance (Cap. 285).

subsection.content: An occupational safety officer may at any time after informing the proprietor or, if the proprietor is not readily available, a foreman or other responsible person in the industrial undertaking, take for analysis sufficient samples of any material in use or mixed for use in a dangerous trade or scheduled trade, or of any substance used or intended to be used in an industrial undertaking being a substance which he thinks may prove on analysis to be likely to cause bodily injury to the person employed. (32 of 2000 s. 48)

subsection.leadIn: The proprietor or the foreman or other responsible person aforesaid may, at the time when a sample is taken under this regulation, and on providing the necessary appliances, require the occupational safety officer to divide the sample into 3 parts, to mark and seal or fasten up each part in such manner as its nature permits, and— (32 of 2000 s. 48)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to deliver one part to the proprietor, or the foreman or other responsible person aforesaid;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to retain one part for future comparison; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to submit one part to the Government Chemist for analysis.

subsection.content: A certificate purporting to be a certificate by the Government Chemist as to the result to an analysis of a sample under this regulation shall in any proceedings under the Ordinance be admissible as evidence of the matters stated therein, but either party may require the person by whom the analysis was made to be called as a witness.

No person shall, except in so far as is necessary for the purposes of a prosecution for an offence under the Ordinance, publish or disclose to any person the results of an analysis made under this regulation.

No person employed in an industrial undertaking shall wilfully interfere with or misuse any means, appliance, convenience or other thing provided in pursuance of the Ordinance for securing the health, safety or welfare of the persons employed in the industrial undertaking, and where any means or appliance for securing health or safety is provided for the use of any such person under the Ordinance, he shall use the means or appliance.

section.name: s22
section.heading: Application of this Part
section.content: This Part (except regulation 23) shall apply to every notifiable workplace that is an industrial undertaking.

section.name: s23
section.heading: Form of notification and prohibition notice
section.content: Every notification under section 9 of the Ordinance and every prohibition notice under section 9A of the Ordinance shall be in such form as the Commissioner for Labour may from time to time approve by notice in the Gazette.

section.name: s24
section.heading: Fencing of dangerous platforms, liquids, etc.
section.leadIn: In every notifiable workplace— (50 of 1985 s. 9)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: all platforms, pits and openings in floors and every other place liable to be dangerous to persons; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: all vessels containing any scalding, corrosive or poisonous liquid,

section.continued: shall be securely fenced to a height of not less than 900 millimetres or otherwise protected to the satisfaction of the Commissioner. (L.N. 238 of 1984)

section.name: s25
section.heading: Cleaning of dangerous machinery by young persons

subsection.content: No young person shall be permitted to clean any dangerous part of the machinery in a notifiable workplace while the machinery is in motion by the aid of any mechanical power. For the purpose of this paragraph, such parts of the machinery shall be presumed to be dangerous as are notified by an occupational safety officer to the proprietor of the notifiable workplace. (50 of 1985 s. 9; 32 of 2000 s. 48)
No young person shall be permitted to clean any mill-gearing while such mill-gearing is in motion for the purpose of propelling any part of the machinery in a notifiable workplace.

subsection.leadIn: Every notifiable workplace shall be kept in a clean state, and free from effluvia arising from any drain, sanitary convenience or nuisance, and, without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing provisions—

paragraph.name: a
b
c
paragraph.content: all inside walls and partitions, and all ceilings or tops of rooms shall be limewashed at least once in every year or, if they have been oil-painted or varnished, they shall be washed with hot water and soap at least once in every period of 14 months and repainted or varnished at least once in every period of 42 months.

subsection.leadIn: The proprietor of a notifiable workplace shall maintain a record of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the surfaces within the notifiable workplace which have been limewashed in accordance with paragraph (1)(c); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the painted and varnished surfaces within the notifiable workplace and the parts thereof which have been washed, or repainted or revarnished, in accordance with paragraph (1)(c); and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the name and address of each person who carried out such work and the date or dates on which the work was carried out.

subsection.content: The proprietor of a notifiable workplace shall produce the record maintained under paragraph (2) for inspection when required to do so by an occupational safety officer. (32 of 2000 s. 48)

In every notifiable workplace, effective and suitable provision shall be made for securing and maintaining by the circulation of fresh air in each workroom or, in the case of a mine, in each shaft, the adequate ventilation of the room or shaft, and for rendering harmless, so far as practicable, all fumes, dust and other impurities that may be injurious to health generated in the course of any process or work carried on in the notifiable workplace.

Without prejudice to the generality of paragraph (1), in every notifiable workplace in which, in connexion with any process or work carried on, there is given off any dust or fume or other impurity of such a character and to such extent as to be likely to be injurious or offensive to the persons employed, or any substantial quantity of dust of any kind, all practicable steps shall be taken to protect the persons employed against inhalation of the dust or fume or other impurity and to prevent its accumulating in any workroom, and in particular, where the nature of the process makes it practicable, exhaust appliances shall be provided and maintained, as near as possible to the point of origin of the dust or fume or other impurity, so as to prevent its entering the air of any workroom. (71 of 1989 s. 13; L.N. 235 of 1996)

Effective provision shall be made for securing and maintaining sufficient and suitable lighting, whether natural or artificial, in every part of a notifiable workplace in which persons are working or passing.

content.leadIn: All glazed windows and skylights used for the lighting of workrooms in any notifiable workplace shall, so far as practicable, be kept clean on both the inner and outer surfaces and free from obstruction: (71 of 1989 s. 13)
content.proviso: Provided that any such window or skylight may be white-washed or shaded for the purpose of mitigating heat or glare.

subsection.content: Where, in any notifiable workplace, any process or work is carried on which renders the floor liable to be wet to such extent that the moisture is capable of being removed by drainage, effective means shall be provided and maintained for draining off the moisture. (50 of 1985 s. 9)
Any means for draining which does not comply with the provisions of the Buildings Ordinance (Cap. 123) shall be deemed not to be effective for the purpose of this regulation.
A notifiable workplace shall not, while work is carried on, be so overcrowded as to cause risk of injury to the health of the persons employed therein.

Without prejudice to the generality of paragraph (1), a notifiable workplace shall be deemed to be so overcrowded as aforesaid, if the number of persons employed at a time in any workroom is such that the amount of cubic space allowed for every person employed in the room is less than 7 cubic metres. (L.N. 238 of 1984)
In every room in every notifiable workplace a notice shall be posted specifying the number of persons who, having regard to the provisions of this regulation, may be employed in the room.

Every notifiable workplace shall be provided with sufficient and suitable latrine and washing conveniences on the premises and, where persons of both sexes are or are intended to be employed such conveniences shall afford proper separate accommodation for persons of each sex. (50 of 1985 s. 9)

Any latrine or washing convenience which does not comply with the provisions of the Buildings Ordinance (Cap. 123) shall be deemed not to be sufficient and suitable for the purpose of this regulation.

section.name: s38
section.heading: Supply of drinking water
section.content: In every notifiable workplace an adequate supply of drinking water either from a public main or from a source approved in writing by a health officer shall be provided and maintained at suitable points conveniently accessible to all persons employed.

subsection.content: All the floors, walls, ceilings, windows and skylights of a notifiable workplace shall be maintained in a good state of repair and free from spalls.

The surface of all the floors of a notifiable workplace shall be rendered and maintained in an even and non-slippery condition and the floors shall be kept free from any obstruction or hazard which might cause a person to fall down or stumble by tripping or otherwise.
In a notifiable workplace all goods and materials shall be stored, stacked or otherwise arranged in such a manner that no danger is caused to any person.

section.name: s44
section.heading: Contravention of regulation 16F(2) or 20(4) is offence
section.content: A person who contravenes regulation 16F(2) or 20(4) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 4.

section.name: s44A
section.heading: Contravention of regulation 21 is offence
section.content: A person who contravenes regulation 21 commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5.

section.name: s45
section.heading: Contravention of regulation 16C(1) or (2), 24, 25, 33 or 36(1) is offence

subsection.leadIn: The proprietor of any industrial undertaking or of any notifiable workplace, as the case may be,—

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in which any person is permitted to do anything in contravention of any of the provisions of regulation 16C(1) or (2) or 25; or (5 of 2023 s. 18)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in respect of which any of the provisions of regulation 24, 33 or 36(1) are contravened,

subsection.leadIn: A person who is convicted of an offence under paragraph (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in respect of a contravention of regulation 16C(1), 25 or 33 is liable to a fine at level 6;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in respect of a contravention of regulation 16C(2) or 36(1) is liable to a fine at level 4; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: in respect of a contravention of regulation 24 is liable to—

subparagraph.content: if the offence was committed without reasonable excuse—a fine of $400,000 and to imprisonment for 12 months; or
in any other case—a fine of $400,000. (5 of 2023 s. 18)

section.name: s46
section.heading: Contravention of regulation 16B, 34, 37(1), 38 or 39 is offence

subsection.leadIn: The proprietor of any industrial undertaking or of any notifiable workplace, as the case may be,—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: who contravenes any of the provisions of regulation 16B; or (L.N. 239 of 1992)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in respect of which any of the provisions of regulation 34, 37(1), 38 or 39 are contravened,

subsection.leadIn: A person who is convicted of an offence under paragraph (1)—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: in respect of a contravention of regulation 34 or 38 is liable to a fine at level 5; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in respect of a contravention of regulation 39 is liable to a fine at level 6. (5 of 2023 s. 19)

section.name: s47
section.heading: Contravention of regulation 17, 18, 32, 35(1) or 36(3) is offence

subsection.leadIn: The proprietor of any industrial undertaking or of any notifiable workplace, as the case may be,—

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in respect of which any of the provisions of regulation 32, 35(1) or 36(3) are contravened; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: who, without reasonable excuse, fails to make any report required by regulation 17 or 18, or who makes such a report which he knows to be false in any material particular, (L.N. 7 of 1975)

subsection.continued: shall be guilty of an offence. (G.N.A. 71 of 1958; L.N. 157 of 1978; L.N. 114 of 1981; 50 of 1985 s. 9)

subsection.leadIn: A person who is convicted of an offence under paragraph (1)—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: in respect of a contravention of regulation 32, 35(1) or 36(3) is liable to a fine at level 4. (5 of 2023 s. 20)

section.name: s48
section.heading: Liability of proprietors
section.content: Notwithstanding anything contained in section 13 of the Ordinance, the proprietor of an industrial undertaking in or in respect of which an offence against regulation 20(4) or 21 is committed shall not be guilty of a like offence.

section.name: s1
section.content: Bursting of a revolving vessel, wheel, grindstone or grinding wheel moved by mechanical power.

section.name: s2
section.content: Collapse or failure of a crane, derrick, winch, hoist or other appliance (but not including a builder’s lift or tower working platform to which the Builders’ Lifts and Tower Working Platforms (Safety) Ordinance (Cap. 470) applies) used in raising or lowering persons or goods or any part thereof (except the breakage of chain or rope slings), or the overturning of a crane. (L.N. 548 of 1995)

section.name: s3
section.content: Explosion or fire causing damage to the structure of any room or place in which persons are employed, or to any machine or plant contained therein and resulting in the complete suspension of ordinary work in such room or place.

section.name: s4
section.content: Electrical short circuit or failure of electrical machinery, plant or apparatus, attended by explosion or fire or causing structural damage thereto, and involving its stoppage or disuse.

section.name: s5
section.content: Explosion of a receiver or container used for the storage at a pressure greater than atmospheric pressure of any gas or gases (including air) or any liquid or solid resulting from the compression of gas.

section.name: s6
section.content: Collapse in whole or part from any cause whatsoever of any roof, wall, floor, structure or foundation forming part of the premises of an industrial undertaking in which persons are employed.

section.name: s7
section.content: Total or partial collapse of any overburden, face, tip or embankment in a quarry. (L.N. 29 of 1969)

section.name: s8
section.content: Overturning of, or collision with any object by, any bulldozer, dumper, excavator, grader, lorry or shovel loader, or any mobile machine used for the handling of any substance in a quarry.
